Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 0b2cbd32d98bde0d88ffe98b64abb1446439cdc4

Hi all,

You can find out more information about the properties of this interface from the 6.6.2 to 6.6.5 chapter of DCMI specification 1.5 (https://www.intel.com/content/dam/www/public/us/en/documents/technical-specifications/dcmi-v1-5-rev-spec.pdf).

Please help me review this interface.

Thanks.
The link is broken.
I update link: https://www.intel.com/content/dam/www/public/us/en/documents/technical-specifications/dcmi-v1-5-rev-spec.pdf

The Active and PowerLimits properties have already been defined in Control/Power/Cap.interface.yaml
Is there a reason you could not update that file to add the additional parameters instead of duplicating?
Thank you for your suggestion, I will move those changes to Control/Power/Cap.interface.yaml file.
I moved those changes to Control/Power/Cap.interface.yaml, please help me to review.

Units are not listed here.
I believe the standard for time based properties should have a type of uint64 and be in units of milliseconds.
👍 .  See EpochTime interface for the canonical way we represent time.
I updated the description to mention units of CorrectionTime.
Don't use uint16 on this either.
In the DCMI specification, the unit of SamplingPeriod is second and the number of bytes to describe SamplingPeriod is 2. Therefore, I think the type of this property should be unit16
What are these??

I see this in the DCMI spec:

> 02h – 10h OEM defined actions

This is unacceptable in a dbus interface.

In the ipmitool, it is supporting to configuration exception action is OEM_02/03../0F/10. Therefore, the Dbus-interface should include those options. The application which implements this interface can call a service to handle OEM actions, users can override this service to implement their exception action.

We need to find another solution.  I'm not accepting undocumented "OEM" properties that just mirror some IPMI specification.  If we did this everywhere we'd end up with dbus being the _worst_ of all interfaces because it would take all the bad stuff from every "standard" in the world.

If you have an explicit need for some specific OEM behaviors here, please document them with real readable property descriptions and names.

Making ipmitool work out of the box is not high on my list of concerns.  We can always reject when someone tries to set OEMxx on the IPMI response.

Depending on the platform, the algorithm to control the system when the total power consumption exceeds the power limit can be different, therefore an OEM action is necessary.

What do you think if I merge all OEMxx actions into one OEM? And add a description that "OEM defined action. Depending on the platform, users can define their BMC's behavior when the total power consumption exceeds the power limit. Users have to update the source code to implement this algorithm, depending on the application which implements this interface, it can be a service or script file."

It appears that Redfish has the following:

```
        "PowerLimitException": {
            "enum": [
                "NoAction",
                "HardPowerOff",
                "LogEventOnly",
                "Oem"
            ],
```

Let's match that.  Notice also that they don't use "SEL".

I updated the values of "ExceptionActions" enum as Redfish except for the "Invalid" value.

I still keep the name of this enum as "ExceptionActions", not "PowerLimitException", because I think we don't have to add the prefix "PowerLimit" in this interface.

Please take a look.
Still need the type and units on these two time properties to match EpochTime.
I updated the type/unit of "CorrectionTime" and "SamplingPeriod" properties to "uint64"/"microseconds". Please take a look.
I'm not sure if all this text is useful.
I removed this redundant description.

Hi @Patrick & @Chris,
Do you have any comments for this patch?

Does this need a default value?
Wondering what the default should be since this is new property.  Oem? or NoAction?
Definitely NoAction, which is implied by it being the first enumeration value, but we should add it explicitly here.
I updated default ExceptionAction's value to "NoAction"
Do you want 0 as the default?  I guess if NoAction is the action it probably doesn't matter.
I set the default value to 0.
Your prior default was 1 sec, but now that is 1 microsecond.  Was that your intention?
Thank your for your comment, I updated this value to 1000000
